docs.lead_paragraph: China's Foreign Minister today called on President Clinton to make a public statement during his state visit this week restating American opposition to any move by Taiwan toward independence. headline.main: EX-CHINESE LEADER CONFRONTS BEIJING ON 1989 MASSACRE

docs.snippet: Zhao Ziyang, who was ousted as Communist Party chief at the time of the crackdown in Tiananmen Square in 1989, has challenged the nation's leaders to admit that the incident was not only reprehensible but also an immense political blunder.     Mr. Zh
docs.lead_paragraph: Zhao Ziyang, who was ousted as Communist Party chief at the time of the crackdown in Tiananmen Square in 1989, has challenged the nation's leaders to admit that the incident was not only reprehensible but also an immense political blunder. Mr. Zhao, who has been under house arrest for nine years, made his case in a letter to the party's Central Committee by arguing that President Clinton's visit to China, which begins today, offered a chance to reverse the official verdict on the massacre that bloodied the streets of Beijing and deeply scarred the nation's conscience. The Communist Party has insisted that the Government had to call in the military to quell a ''counter-revolutionary rebellion.''

docs.abstract: Editorial urges Pres Clinton to assert American values during visit to Tiananmen Square in Beijing, where hundreds of peaceful pro-democracy demonstrators were massacred in 1989; says Clinton can honor them by describing their sacrifice as reminder of how far China and its leaders must travel (M)
docs.snippet: We would feel more confident about the lasting value of President Clinton's trip to China, which begins today, if we knew that someone had included among his briefing papers a summary of Ronald Reagan's extraordinary visit to the Soviet Union in 1988
docs.lead_paragraph: We would feel more confident about the lasting value of President Clinton's trip to China, which begins today, if we knew that someone had included among his briefing papers a summary of Ronald Reagan's extraordinary visit to the Soviet Union in 1988. Mr. Reagan used that trip to meet with prominent dissidents and speak directly to Soviet audiences about fundamental freedoms and the advantages of democracy, and there was little that his host, Mikhail Gorbachev, could do about it but grumble. Mr. Reagan knew that one of the important powers of a traveling President is the right to speak plainly in lands unaccustomed to open debate. Bill Clinton has the same luxury. The cause of human rights will be poorer if he squanders it. Mr. Clinton's aides have said he will address the issue in some way, and there is no shortage of promising venues. His itinerary includes a small village that has just conducted its first open election, an ecumenical church and a classroom at Beijing University. But there is one obvious setting in which Mr. Clinton can seize the moment, politely but firmly, to assert American values. That is Tiananmen Square, which he will visit on Saturday, and where hundreds of peaceful pro-democracy demonstrators were slaughtered on June 4, 1989.

docs.snippet: Tiananmen Square is the symbolic center of Communist China.    It is where Mao Zedong proclaimed the founding of the People's  Republic in 1949, where millions of Red Guards gathered in the political frenzy of the 1960's, and where students spontaneo
docs.lead_paragraph: Tiananmen Square is the symbolic center of Communist China. It is where Mao Zedong proclaimed the founding of the People's Republic in 1949, where millions of Red Guards gathered in the political frenzy of the 1960's, and where students spontaneously convened the largest demonstrations in the nation's history to demand greater democracy during the spring of 1989.

docs.abstract: Editorial holds China has seriously embarrassed Pres Clinton by detaining democracy advocates during his stop in Xian and by imposing heavy surveillance on other democrats in Beijing; holds he must respond personally, publicly and bluntly
docs.snippet: The ceremonial part of President Clinton's welcome may be fit for an emperor, but other aspects of the Chinese Government's behavior have looked like calculated insults. By detaining several democracy advocates during the President's stop in Xian and
docs.lead_paragraph: The ceremonial part of President Clinton's welcome may be fit for an emperor, but other aspects of the Chinese Government's behavior have looked like calculated insults. By detaining several democracy advocates during the President's stop in Xian and imposing heavy surveillance on other democrats in Beijing, Chinese leaders have seriously embarrassed Mr. Clinton. He must respond personally, publicly and bluntly. As Beijing well knows, Mr. Clinton took considerable political risks to go through with this trip. By making his presence a pretext for picking up political activists, China's leaders demonstrated indifference to his efforts on their behalf.

headline.main: The Campaign Never Rests: On the Road in China, Clinton Was Right at Home

docs.snippet: As President Clinton traveled through China, his permanent campaign rolled on.     In Shanghai on Wednesday, for example, the President spoke at a Chamber of Commerce breakfast, chatted with students at a cybercafe, shmoozed with traders on the floor
docs.lead_paragraph: As President Clinton traveled through China, his permanent campaign rolled on. In Shanghai on Wednesday, for example, the President spoke at a Chamber of Commerce breakfast, chatted with students at a cybercafe, shmoozed with traders on the floor of the Shanghai Stock Exchange, hyped home ownership to residents of a new apartment complex and sat for an interview with Chinese state television. Pretty much like any other day on the road in America.

docs.lead_paragraph: The superlatives are swirling around the ''Turandot'' that will be mounted this September in a 500-year-old courtyard of the Forbidden City here. With Zubin Mehta as conductor and artistic chief, the Chinese filmmaker Zhang Yimou as director and a colorful temple where emperors once offered sacrifices to their ancestors as a backdrop, this production is sure to be an Event.

headline.main: 40 Years of Opera House Plans, but Still No Music

docs.snippet: In a city where real estate prices have skyrocketed, where developers compete to put up glitzy apartment complexes and shopping centers, it is little short of stunning that this capital's best-located empty lot has remained just that -- empty -- for
docs.lead_paragraph: In a city where real estate prices have skyrocketed, where developers compete to put up glitzy apartment complexes and shopping centers, it is little short of stunning that this capital's best-located empty lot has remained just that -- empty -- for 40 years. Situated across the street from the Great Hall of the People and a stone's throw from Zhongnanhai, the secretive compound where China's leaders live and work, this parcel of land is about as prime as you can find in all of China. Today it serves as a sunken parking lot for mail trucks, and is surrounded by dilapidated shacks where a few dozen itinerant workers bunk.

headline.main: Jailing of Ex-Mayor Shows a Tougher China

docs.snippet: The 16-year sentence given today to Chen Xitong, the powerful former Mayor and Communist Party boss of Beijing, is intended to show that China's leaders are serious about cracking down on the corruption that is eating away at the core of their author
docs.lead_paragraph: The 16-year sentence given today to Chen Xitong, the powerful former Mayor and Communist Party boss of Beijing, is intended to show that China's leaders are serious about cracking down on the corruption that is eating away at the core of their authority. Mr. Chen was found guilty by a Beijing court of corruption and dereliction of duty, the state news media reported. He is the only member of the party's ruling Politburo to be jailed since the show trials of the so-called Gang of Four, the leftists who were ousted from power 20 years ago.
